d: A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
e: the ache in her head worsened

d: A damaging immune response by the body to a substance, especially pollen, fur, a particular food, or dust, to which it has become hypersensitive.
e: Symptoms of a food allergy usually develop within about an hour after eating the offending food.

d: A drug or other compound that inhibits the physiological effects of histamine, used especially in the treatment of allergies.
e: Hay fever or some old fashioned antihistamine treatments with side effect drowsiness can generally impede your life style.

d: A natural desire to satisfy a bodily need, especially for food.
e: he has a healthy appetite

d: A synthetic compound used medicinally to relieve mild or chronic pain and to reduce fever and inflammation.
e: Ask any medical student and he or she will tell you that aspirin reduces fever, pain, and inflammation but may cause ulcers.

d: A strip of material used to bind a wound or to protect an injured part of the body.
e: her leg was swathed in bandages

d: The red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins of humans and other vertebrate animals, carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues of the body.
e: drops of blood

d: Any of the pieces of hard whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
e: his injuries included many broken bones

d: Having been fractured or damaged and no longer in one piece or in working order.
e: he had a broken arm

d: Inflammation of the mucous membrane in the bronchial tubes. It typically causes bronchospasm and coughing.
e: Rarely, flu can develop into a high fever, acute bronchitis, encephalitis and pneumonia.

d: An injury appearing as an area of discolored skin on the body, caused by a blow or impact rupturing underlying blood vessels.
e: his body was a mass of bruises after he had been attacked

d: Cause (light or shadow) to appear on a surface.
e: the moon cast a pale light over the cottages

d: An establishment or hospital department where outpatients are given medical treatment or advice, especially of a specialist nature.
e: a mental health clinic

d: Of or at a low or relatively low temperature, especially when compared with the human body.
e: a freezing cold day

d: (of a disease) spread from one person or organism to another by direct or indirect contact.
e: a contagious infection

d: Expel air from the lungs with a sudden sharp sound.
e: he tried to speak and started to cough

d: A long stick with a crosspiece at the top, used as a support under the armpit by a person with an injury or disability.
e: It's difficult to understand why so many crutches, white sticks and wheelchairs remain unclaimed.

d: Make an opening, incision, or wound in (something) with a sharp-edged tool or object.
e: he cut his toe on a sharp stone

d: (chiefly of a medicine) used to relieve nasal congestion.
e: decongestant nasal sprays can ease swollen nasal passages

d: A condition in which feces are discharged from the bowels frequently and in a liquid form.
e: a range of symptoms including diarrhea and vomiting

d: Having or involving a sensation of spinning around and losing one's balance.
e: Jonathan had begun to suffer dizzy spells

d: An abnormally high body temperature, usually accompanied by shivering, headache, and in severe instances, delirium.
e: I would take aspirin to help me with the pain and reduce the fever

d: Help given to a sick or injured person until full medical treatment is available.
e: an expert in emergency first aid

d: short for influenza
e: I had a bad case of the flu

d: A continuous pain in the head.
e: I've got a splitting headache

d: A rash of round, red welts on the skin that itch intensely, sometimes with dangerous swelling, caused by an allergic reaction, typically to specific foods.
e: Stress worsens many skin conditions - such as psoriasis, eczema, hives and acne - and can be a trigger for asthma attacks.

d: Pain or discomfort in the stomach associated with difficulty in digesting food.
e: you know chips give me indigestion

d: The process of infecting or the state of being infected.
e: strict hygiene will limit the risk of infection

d: A highly contagious viral infection of the respiratory passages causing fever, severe aching, and catarrh, and often occurring in epidemics.
e: Other viral illnesses include influenza, the common cold, Lassa fever, and ebola.

d: An instance of injecting or being injected.
e: painkilling injections

d: An instance of being injured.
e: she suffered an injury to her back

d: A substance used for medical treatment, especially a medicine or drug.
e: certain medications can cause dizziness

d: A band or bundle of fibrous tissue in a human or animal body that has the ability to contract, producing movement in or maintaining the position of parts of the body.
e: the calf muscle

d: A feeling of sickness with an inclination to vomit.
e: a wave of nausea engulfed him

d: Physical suffering or discomfort caused by illness or injury.
e: she's in great pain

d: (of a part of the body) affected with pain.
e: her ankle was very painful

d: (of a medical practitioner) advise and authorize the use of (a medicine or treatment) for someone, especially in writing.
e: Dr. Greene prescribed magnesium sulfate

d: An instruction written by a medical practitioner that authorizes a patient to be provided a medicine or treatment.
e: he scribbled a prescription for tranquilizers

d: Displaying or proceeding from a lack of careful consideration of the possible consequences of an action.
e: it would be extremely rash to make such an assumption

d: The firing of a gun or cannon.
e: he brought down a caribou with a single shot to the neck

d: Make a sudden involuntary expulsion of air from the nose and mouth due to irritation of one's nostrils.
e: the smoke made her sneeze

d: (of a part of one's body) painful or aching.
e: my feet were sore and my head ached

d: A strip of rigid material used for supporting and immobilizing a broken bone when it has been set.
e: she had to wear splints on her legs

d: Wrench or twist the ligaments of (an ankle, wrist, or other joint) violently so as to cause pain and swelling but not dislocation.
e: he left in a wheelchair after spraining an ankle

d: The internal organ in which the major part of the digestion of food occurs, being (in humans and many mammals) a pear-shaped enlargement of the alimentary canal linking the esophagus to the small intestine.
e: severe stomach pains

d: A flexible but inelastic cord of strong fibrous collagen tissue attaching a muscle to a bone.
e: A physical examination will determine if damage to tissue, nerves, tendons, or bone has occurred.

d: An instrument for measuring and indicating temperature, typically one consisting of a narrow, hermetically sealed glass tube marked with graduations and having at one end a bulb containing mercury or alcohol that expands and contracts in the tube with heating and cooling.
e: Narrow-range mercury thermometers were used to measure sand surface temperature.

d: An infective agent that typically consists of a nucleic acid molecule in a protein coat, is too small to be seen by light microscopy, and is able to multiply only within the living cells of a host.
e: a virus infection

d: Eject matter from the stomach through the mouth.
e: the sickly stench made him want to vomit

d: A room provided for the use of people who are waiting to be seen by a doctor or dentist or who are waiting in a station for a bus or train.
e: Many ICUs do not have private rooms near waiting rooms where doctors and nurses can consult and inform family members in confidence.

d: An injury to living tissue caused by a cut, blow, or other impact, typically one in which the skin is cut or broken.
e: a knife wound
